author: prajwolrg
content:
Hi, I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask this question. 
But I was learning about the Ethereum PoS and was looking into the beacon chain explorer.

In the #votes tab of a slot, I saw the following
"32076 validators voted 32573 times for this block:" [Example](https://beaconcha.in/slot/9387190#votes)

How do we interpret this?

author: potuz
content:
I think the explorer counts as vote whenever an attestation for this block appears in other blocks. The typical situation would be this
```
N <- N+1
```
During `N` validators vote for it and they are included in `N+1`, now the next block appears and does
```
N <- N+1
\_________ N+2
```
And includes again the same attestations that were included in `N+1`. I think in this case the explorer counts this attestations twice. 

On top of this, validators are allowed to include multiple times the same attestations in blocks, they are just worthless, they give nothing to the proposer nor the attester. We recently received a report that Prysm may be including twice the same attestations in some cases after 32 slots, so this would also contribute to this.

author: prajwolrg
content:
1. In case of a fork as:
```N <- N+1
\_________ N+2
```
I understood that the 64 committees assigned for the blocks N+1 and N+2 are disjoint. So there will be no common votes.

2. For validators being allowed to include multiple attestations, how does that work? Will the validator (or maybe case the proposer)  include aggregated BLS signature of one committee (say A) as well as also include another aggregated signature that includes some members of A again?

author: potuz
content: 1. They are both including the same committee: that of N

author: potuz
content: 2 yes, and you can even include the very same aggregate if you want

author: prajwolrg
content: So, even though chain progress on either N+1/N+2 both the attestations are considered by the explorer?

author: potuz
content: That's my guess, it was like this at the beginning at least. You could check on  reorgs, not sure if it was fixed
